messageBody:
We do the following with Test Mentor (a commercial component testing tool),
but you could probably extend JUnit in a similar way:

We provide a sort of managed variable scheme within the context of an
executing test, respective of scope (tests in Test Mentor can be recursively
defined, if you like), that's basically a bunch of java.util.Hashtables,
each tied to a particular scoping level. These Hashtable values are
accessible by APIs within the tool that resolve the correct value, depending
on the context of the executing test. The APIs make it pretty transparent,
relying mostly on a test execution context stack that tracks whichever
Hashtable should be active at the moment. The APIs (which any test inherits)
look something like getLocalVar(name) and setLocalVar(name,value). So you
could instantiate/execute a test that sets variables, which then
instantiates/exeuctes another test within it that may or may not set
variables with the same name, and the tool will handle variable name scope
resolution automatically.
